column4: Hello, I do not get any network access to my router or the WAN following a hard crash last night.. I get assigned an IP address via DHCP but ping is not possible etc.. any ideas?
are you running any firewalls?
I havent got firestarter installed, i didnt change iptables rules or anything
what kind of response do you get back from pinging your router?
ping: sendmsg: Operation not permitted

Everything was workign fine until laptop ran out of battery last night (hardcrash). Now it seems upset.. eth1 and eth0 both display this behaviour, other LAN clients working fine. IP address is assigned by router, but DNS servers are not fed through properly
what is in your /etc/network/interfaces file?
I checked it after googling web forums.. it looks nearly empty,"auto Io iface Io inet loopback"
seems like your eth0 and eth1 are missing
I see, the network
I seemed to think that nm was just a front for interfaces file
maybe i am mistaken
baschule: I would think so too, hence the surprise - nm-applet "connection information" shows  fixed IP for machine applied correctly, but primary DNS stays on router IP
ifconfig also shows ip address as assigned by router
maybe try editing /etc/network/interfaces by hand and restarting networking (lets rule out nm for sure)
maybe i should do the interfaces manually, do I have to deactivate nm-applet
you can kill the nm if you want and manually config the interfaces if you want
i shall try that
killed nm-app, defined wlan using network-manager, now interfaces file shows "iface eth1 inet dhcp, wpa....auto eth1" ping still says operation not permitted
are you trying to ping by host name or dns? can the router ping you? (provided iptables is disabled)
bascule so it was a firewall issue all along? I thought that was off ages ago...... lol
bascule would it be worth considering firestater (or similar) ??
sorry, didnt copy you in, I just used the firestarter wizard to create a config
bascule ah. I havent used iptables for a while now... looks like im going rusty...... time to replace my Cisco 837 with iptables :)
